channel.title: When some else uses my client my username and pass are still there (solved)
channel.description: is there any way to change this because one of my friends was able to get onto my account because he downloaded my client im using deathlypvp v3 if anyone could help that would be great

item.title: When some else uses my client my username and pass are still there (solved)
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Solution 1:
Delete the .ini file that saves your username and password to the cache (As WarTusk-RSPS explained above).
Solution 2:
Login with false credentials (Example: An account with the user and pass as “test”) and then create the cache .zip. That way all users will get that as their default login, not yours.

Read full topic
item.source: When some else uses my client my username and pass are still there (solved)

item.title: When some else uses my client my username and pass are still there (solved)
item.dc:creator: @WarTusk-RSPS WarTusk-RSPS
item.description:
@WarTusk-RSPS wrote:

in your cache there is a saveuser.ini or something like that where any account you login to last it will save the username and password in the cache. so when you open the client your username and pass will be there still in that cache they download. When you upload your cache to drop box just make sure your username and password are not saved in the file. And it will not be a problem at all.

Read full topic
item.source: When some else uses my client my username and pass are still there (solved)

item.title: When some else uses my client my username and pass are still there (solved)

item.source: When some else uses my client my username and pass are still there (solved)

item.title: When some else uses my client my username and pass are still there (solved)
item.dc:creator: @Skyro Arbe
item.description:
@Skyro wrote:

Go into your client folders, and in the java file ‘Client.java’ search for ‘myPassword’ and it will show ‘myUsername’ and ‘myPassword’ and remove those two lines of code.

Read full topic
